misconceptions.name: Reads three doubles instead of five integers
misconceptions.description: The program reads exactly three double values (v0, v1, t) instead of reading five integers as required, so it cannot process the correct amount and type of input for the problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can solve the task by reading three numeric values (as doubles) for an acceleration formula instead of reading five integers from the user.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read exactly five integers from the user (using methods like nextInt) because the problem asks for processing 5 integer inputs.
symptoms: Program prompts for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers
Uses nextDouble three times instead of reading five values
No way to supply five integer inputs as required
misconceptions.root_cause: The student seems to have reused a template for a different physics problem and did not adapt the input-reading logic to this assignment’s specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the input to read five integers (e.g., with nextInt) and ensure that exactly five numbers are requested from the user.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The prompt text and the three calls to nextDouble clearly indicate the program is built for a different three-value problem.

evidence.note: Prompt and three nextDouble calls show the program reads three doubles, not five integers.

misconceptions.name: No loop used to process multiple inputs
misconceptions.description: The student reads each value with separate statements and does not use any loop to process multiple inputs, so the program cannot scale to reading and handling five numbers in a structured way.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can solve the problem by writing a few individual input statements and do not need a loop to handle multiple values.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To process five numbers according to the specification, a loop should be used to repeatedly read and handle each of the five inputs.
symptoms: No for, while, or do-while loop is present
Inputs are read by a fixed number of explicit nextDouble calls
Cannot easily generalize to handle exactly five values as a group
misconceptions.root_cause: The student may not recognize that reading multiple similar inputs is best handled with a loop, or they are focused on a different pre-existing example that reads a fixed small set of values.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a loop (for or while) that iterates five times, reading one number per iteration and processing it inside the loop body.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code contains three explicit input reads and no loop constructs at all, in a task that explicitly calls for processing multiple inputs.

evidence.note: Three explicit input reads with no surrounding loop indicate the absence of a loop structure for multiple inputs.

misconceptions.name: No conditional check for even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program never tests whether a number is even (using n % 2 == 0 or similar), so it cannot filter and sum only the even numbers as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can compute the desired result without needing to check whether each input is even.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To sum only even numbers, each input must be tested with a conditional, such as if (n % 2 == 0), before adding it to the running total.
symptoms: No use of the modulus operator (%)
No if-statement or boolean check related to evenness
All logic is devoted to a physics formula instead of conditional filtering
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to be implementing a completely different problem (average acceleration) and thus omitted any conditional filtering based on evenness.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce an if-statement inside the input-processing loop that checks n % 2 == 0 before adding the value to the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: No modulus operator or condition appears anywhere, and the only calculation is a simple arithmetic formula unrelated to evenness.

evidence.note: The only computation uses a physics formula; there is no conditional logic to check even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Computes average acceleration instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: Rather than using an accumulator variable to add up even numbers, the program calculates average acceleration from physics ( (v1 - v0) / t ) and prints that value.
misconceptions.student_belief: Solving the task means computing and printing the average acceleration using (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should maintain an integer sum that starts at 0, add each even input to this accumulator, and finally print the total sum of the even numbers.
symptoms: No accumulator variable initialized and updated in a loop
Single expression (finalVelocity - v0) / t_val used as the result
Output message refers to 'average acceleration' instead of 'Sum of even numbers'
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely copied or reused code from a textbook or previous exercise on computing average acceleration and did not adjust the logic to match the current problem statement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the physics formula with an integer sum accumulator that is updated when an input is even, and change the final print statement to display the sum of even numbers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Both the variable names and the formula clearly match a standard acceleration example rather than a sum-of-evens problem.

evidence.snippet:
double avg_acceleration = (finalVelocity - v0) / t_val;

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + avg_acceleration);
evidence.note: Shows the use of an average acceleration formula and corresponding output instead of maintaining and printing a sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Missing iterative structure for repeated input
misconceptions.description: The logic lacks the necessary loop structure (e.g., `for` loop) to repeatedly read and process the required 5 inputs.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes all required inputs can be read and processed in a single sequential block of code.
